sen.j: 三方（さんぼう、さんぽう）とは、神道の神事において使われる、神饌を載せるための台である。
sen.e: A sanbo, also known as sanpo, is a stand to place shinsen (food and alcohol offerings to gods) used for Shinto rituals.
A sanbo, also known as a sanpo, is a small stand used in Shinto rituals for presenting shinsen (offerings of food and alcohol) to kami (deities, spirits).

sen.j: 古代には、高貴な人物に物を献上する際にも使用された。
sen.e: In ancient times, this was also used to present something to noble people.
In ancient times, it was also used when presenting things to members of the upper-classes.

sen.j: 寺院でも同様のものが使われるが、三宝（仏・法・僧）にかけて三宝（さんぽう）と書かれることもある。
sen.e: Similar items are used at Buddhist temples as well, and this term is sometimes written in the Chinese characters 三宝 (sanpo), which also represent Triratna (three treasures of Buddhism: Buddha, dharma, and sangha).

Similar items are used at Buddhist temples as well, and the term is sometimes written with the Chinese characters 三宝 (sanpo), which also represent the Triratna, or Three Treasures of Buddhism: Buddha, Dharma (Teachings), and Sangha (Community).

sen.j: 通常はヒノキなどの素木（しらき）による木製で、折敷（おしき）と呼ばれる盆の下に直方体状の台（胴）がついた形をしている。
sen.e: A sanbo is usually made of unfinished wood such as Japanese cypresses, and it consists of a tray called oshiki and a cuboid-shaped base (body) underneath.
A sanbo is usually made of unfinished wood such as Japanese cypress, and consists of a tray called an oshiki on toｐ of a cuboid-shaped base (body).

sen.j: 台の三方向に穴があいていることから、「三方」と呼ばれる。
sen.e: This is called 'sanbo' (literally means three directions) because there are holes on three sides of the base.
The name 'sanbo' (literally 'three sides') comes from the fact that there are holes on three sides of the base.

sen.j: 元々は折敷と台は分離していて使用するときに台の上に折敷を載せており、台に載せずに折敷だけで使用することもあった。
sen.e: The tray used to be separated from the base and it was put on the base before use, and it was sometimes even used by itself without being put on the base.
The tray and the base used to be separate, with the tray put on the base before use and sometimes even used by itself without the base.

sen.j: 今日では折敷と台が完全に結合したものが使用されており、折敷だけで使用するものは三方とは別に用意するようになっている。
sen.e: Today every sanbo for actual use is a complete combination of a tray and a base, and an exclusive tray for separate use is also available aside from sanbo.
These days, the tray is always attached to the base, and a separate tray is available for use aside from the sanbo.

sen.j: 折敷には縁の板を留めるための綴り目があるが、これは穴のない側の反対側になるように作られている。
sen.e: A tray has a seam to fix the edge board, and that seam should be on the opposite side of the side without a hole.
The seam made when the ends of the board that forms the lip of the tray meet should be on the opposite side from the side without a hole.
The seam made when the ends of the board that forms the lip of the tray meet should be on the opposite side from the side without a hole.

sen.j: 神前に供える際は、穴のない側（綴り目の反対側）が神前に向くようにする。
sen.e: When it is offered to a deity, the side without a hole (the side opposite of the seam) should face toward the deity.
When it is offered to a kami, the side without a hole (the side opposite the seam) should face toward the kami.
When it is offered to a kami, the side without a hole (the side opposite the seam) should face toward the kami.

sen.j: 神饌が載った三方を持つときは、親指を左右の縁に、その他の指を折敷と台に当て、目の高さに持つ。
sen.e: When holding a sanbo with offerings on it, people should place their thumbs on the side edges, support the tray and the base with the other fingers, and keep the sanbo at their eye height.
When holding a sanbo with offerings on it, people should place their thumbs on the side edges, support the tray and the base with the other fingers, and keep the sanbo at eye level.
